description: black lacquered chest with ornate mother of pearl inlay; nature scenes on side panels, with trees, grasses, deer on front; drop-down front panel; seven small drawers inside with grasses, flowers, birds, rivers; drawer at center with archway and keyhole, featuring two fish swimming among seaweed
medium: Black lacquer with gold and silver maki-e and mother-of-pearl inlay; metal fittings
text: Created for the export market, this European-style cabinet is covered with design motifs commonly found on <i>Nanban<i> lacquer. <i>Nanban<i> literally means “southern barbarian” and referred to Europeans, mostly Dutch, Portuguese, and Spanish. These foreigners purchased large quantities of Japanese lacquerware to decorate their European homes. In 1610, a lacquer company was established in Amsterdam to meet European demand for these artworks. The cabinet features traditional Japanese motifs, such as waterwheels in a flowing stream. Window-like rectangles bordered with inlaid mother-of-pearl decorate the top and the drop front, which is hinged at the bottom. The eight drawers inside are richly decorated, as are the metal fittings.
title: Nanban cabinet with geometric patterns and deer, birds, fish, plants, and cart wheels partially submerged in water
